doc.field: Liechtenstein's Justice Minister helps to uncover hidden accounts

Liechtenstein's justice minister Frommelt has offered Germany Help with uncovering the CDU's hidden accounts. The foundation "Zaunkoenig" created by Hesses's CDU is located in Liechtenstein. Today, Frommelt met with Germany's Minister of Justice Hertha Daeubler-Gmelin. Their topic was a report by Germany's foreign intelligence service BND. In the report Liechtenstein is called a large laundromat for Columbian drug money. Mr. Frommelt complained that the BND's accusations were sweeping generalizations that the BND could not prove. The intelligence coordinator in the Chancellor's Office, Urlau, was refusing Liechtenstein any information. There was not even a German request for official help. Therefore, Frommelt was appreciating even more that at least his colleague had talked to him. Although she considered herself not in charge for some issues, she had promised to do everything in her powers to improve the international cooperation against organized crime. Liechtenstein's justice minister said that his country at any rate would take care that it would not be an attractive place for money launderers of any kind.
Schleusser admits having had private company on his official flights

North Rhine-Westphalian Finance Minister Heinz Schleusser has admitted that he was accompanied by a woman on his official flights to Yugoslavia. Both times he was using charter flights of Westdeutsche Landesbank. Nonetheless, State Premier Wolfgang Clement supports Schleusser. Clement does not consider Schleusser's admission turns his earlier statement into a lie. Therefore, Mr Schleusser does not have to resign as finance minister, said Clement today in Duesseldorf.
Parliament of Hesse rejects self-dissolution

This afternoon, the legislature of Hesse was voting on its self dissolution. SPD and Alliance90/Gruene had moved the self-dissolution because they accuse the CDU of election fraud. CDU and FDP have a majority of 2 seats in the parliament. With this majority the CDU/FDP coalition defeated the motion 56-54. In connection with the CDU finance affaire, former interior minister Manfred Kanther has formally resigned from his federal mandate. The Bundestag administration has received his letter.
CDU Mecklenburg-Vorpommern did not book money in 1994 election

The CDU of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania has paid part of its 1994 election campaign with money of unclear origin. The accountants of the federal CDU found out that about 150'000 marks have not been booked correctly.
German prosecutors do not investigate Elf-Aquitaine

German prosecutors will not investigate allegations that CDU politicians were bribed by Elf-Aquitaine because the cases would come under the statute of limitations. The French legal authorities had no evidence that the former government company had paid into hidden CDU accounts.
Trade unions initiate pay rounds 2000

In the next pay rounds, IG Bauen, Agrar, Umwelt want to carry through both wage increases and agreed on supplementary rates of 4.8 percent. Meanwhile, IG Metall in the south-west has decided to enter the pay rounds 2000 with a demand for 5.5 percent.
'Collateral damage' declared 1999's worst word

The term 'collateral damage' has been declared the worst words of 1999. It was the term used by NATO for the civilian casualties of the Kosovo war. To the jury made up of linguists and journalists, the word obfuscates the hard facts, that many innocent people were killed due to NATO's intervention. The worst word of the twentieth century is 'human material'.
Border guards arrest international gang of smugglers

The border guards broke up an international smuggler's gang in badem- Wuerttemberg. In the region of Stuttgart 11 smugglers were apprehended. They allegedly smuggled people from Sri Lanka, the Ukraine, Russia and the Chech Republic into Germany.
No compensation from Bosch for former forced labourers

Electronics company Bosch does not have to pay comensation to two former forced labourers for their work during the second world war. The district court of Stuttgart rejected a claim by two Danes on the basis that it no longer falls within the statute of imitations.
30-year limit German nuclear power stations

German nuclear power stations will remain operative for a maximum of 30 years. Besides the Greens, the SPD parliamentary faction has now also reached this decision. The reactors in Stade and Obrigheim, which have been in use for over 30 years, will be granted a transitional period of three years.
Penner appointed commissioner for the armed forces

The SPD faction has appointed their internal affairs expert Wilfried Penner as the next commissioner for the armed forces in parliament. He will be relieving Claire Marienveld, who will not be up for reelection in April.
Heart clinic doctor from the south of Baden murdered
In Stadt, in the south of Baden, a doctor from a heart clinic has been murdered. The police initially assumed death by natural causes, however the autopsy revealed that the doctor was killed.
No more contributions from Daimler-Chrysler after CDU-scandal

Daimler-Chrysler will not make any more contributions to parties for the time being. According to the Welt, other large companies are also considering putting a stop to their contributions until the party contributions affair has been cleared up.
T-online onto the stock market in April
T-online, the largest online provider in Europe, will hit the stock market in April. This has been confirmed by German Telekom, who wishes to retain a majority of the shares of the internet provider.
